title: 109_hr2732
content: The "Cost Integrity and Fairness Act of 2005" is based on Congress's power to levy taxes as per the US Constitution. It introduces a refundable and advanceable credit for health insurance costs in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Cost Integrity and Fairness Act of 2005" introduces a tax credit for qualified health insurance payments made by individuals, limited to monthly amounts based on the number of individuals covered. The "Cost Integrity and Fairness Act of 2005" introduces a tax credit for qualified health insurance payments made by individuals, limited to monthly amounts based on the number of individuals covered. Qualified health insurance is defined as insurance meeting specific requirements. The "Cost Integrity and Fairness Act of 2005" ensures coverage for preexisting medical conditions for continuously insured applicants under specific health insurance programs. The "Cost Integrity and Fairness Act of 2005" guarantees coverage for preexisting medical conditions for continuously insured applicants under certain health insurance programs, with limitations on the exclusion period based on the individual's insurance history. The "Cost Integrity and Fairness Act of 2005" ensures coverage for preexisting medical conditions for continuously insured applicants under specific health insurance programs, with restrictions on the exclusion period based on the individual's insurance history. The act also excludes certain plans from this coverage and includes special rules for coordination with medical deductions. The taxpayer's insurance payments under subsection (a) are not considered for tax credit or deduction purposes. Dependents cannot claim the credit if a deduction is allowed for them. Married couples must file a joint return to claim the credit. The taxpayer must file a joint return with their spouse to claim the credit. Verification of coverage and amount paid for qualified health insurance is required. The credit amount is reduced by advance payments made on behalf of the taxpayer. The taxpayer's credit amount is subject to a cost-of-living adjustment for taxable years after 2005. The increase is determined by multiplying the dollar amount by the cost-of-living adjustment for the calendar year. Any increase is rounded to the nearest multiple of $10. Additionally, there is a provision for the advance payment of the credit in the tax code. The tax code is amended to include a new section after section 7527. "New section 7527A allows for advance payment of credit for health insurance costs." The Secretary will establish a program to make payments for qualified health insurance on behalf of individuals, with limitations on the total amount per individual per taxable year. Conforming amendments are made to related sections of the Internal Revenue Code. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended by adding new items to subchapter A of chapter 1, replacing the item related to section 36. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include new items related to health insurance costs and overpayments of tax. The amendments apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2004.
